com.android.common

Class OperationScheduler

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.android.common.OperationScheduler

  • public class OperationScheduler
extends java.lang.Object
    Tracks the success/failure history of a particular network operation in persistent storage and computes retry strategy accordingly. Handles exponential backoff, periodic rescheduling, event-driven triggering, retry-after moratorium intervals, etc. based on caller-specified parameters.

    This class does not directly perform or invoke any operations, it only keeps track of the schedule. Somebody else needs to call #getNextTimeMillis() as appropriate and do the actual work.

    • Method Detail

      • parseOptions

        public static OperationScheduler.Options parseOptions(java.lang.String spec,
                                                      OperationScheduler.Options options)
                                               throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Parse scheduler options supplied in this string form: 
         backoff=(fixed)+(incremental)[+(exponential)] max=(maxmoratorium) min=(mintrigger) [period=](interval)
        All values are times in (possibly fractional) seconds (not milliseconds). Omitted settings are left at whatever existing default value was passed in.

        The default options: backoff=0+5 max=86400 min=0 period=0
        Fractions are OK: backoff=+2.5 period=10.0
        The "period=" can be omitted: 3600

        Parameters:
        spec - describing some or all scheduler options.
        options - to update with parsed values.
        Returns:
        the options passed in (for convenience)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the syntax is invalid

      • getNextTimeMillis

        public long getNextTimeMillis(OperationScheduler.Options options)
        Compute the time of the next operation. Does not modify any state (unless the clock rolls backwards, in which case timers are reset).
        Parameters:
        options - to use for this computation.
        Returns:
        the wall clock time (System.currentTimeMillis()) when the next operation should be attempted -- immediately, if the return value is before the current time.

      • getLastSuccessTimeMillis

        public long getLastSuccessTimeMillis()
        Return the last time the operation completed. Does not modify any state.
        Returns:
        the wall clock time when onSuccess() was last called.

      • getLastAttemptTimeMillis

        public long getLastAttemptTimeMillis()
        Return the last time the operation was attempted. Does not modify any state.
        Returns:
        the wall clock time when onSuccess() or onTransientError() was last called.

      • setTriggerTimeMillis

        public void setTriggerTimeMillis(long millis)
        Request an operation to be performed at a certain time. The actual scheduled time may be affected by error backoff logic and defined minimum intervals. Use Long.MAX_VALUE to disable triggering.
        Parameters:
        millis - wall clock time (System.currentTimeMillis()) to trigger another operation; 0 to trigger immediately

      • setMoratoriumTimeMillis

        public void setMoratoriumTimeMillis(long millis)
        Forbid any operations until after a certain (absolute) time. Limited by #Options.maxMoratoriumMillis.
        Parameters:
        millis - wall clock time (System.currentTimeMillis()) when operations should be allowed again; 0 to remove moratorium

      • setMoratoriumTimeHttp

        public boolean setMoratoriumTimeHttp(java.lang.String retryAfter)
        Forbid any operations until after a certain time, as specified in the format used by the HTTP "Retry-After" header. Limited by #Options.maxMoratoriumMillis.
        Parameters:
        retryAfter - moratorium time in HTTP format
        Returns:
        true if a time was successfully parsed

      • setEnabledState

        public void setEnabledState(boolean enabled)
        Enable or disable all operations. When disabled, all calls to #getNextTimeMillis() return Long.MAX_VALUE. Commonly used when data network availability goes up and down.
        Parameters:
        enabled - if operations can be performed

      • onSuccess

        public void onSuccess()
        Report successful completion of an operation. Resets all error counters, clears any trigger directives, and records the success.

      • onTransientError

        public void onTransientError()
        Report a transient error (usually a network failure). Increments the error count and records the time of the latest error for backoff purposes.

      • resetTransientError

        public void resetTransientError()
        Reset all transient error counts, allowing the next operation to proceed immediately without backoff. Commonly used on network state changes, when partial progress occurs (some data received), and in other circumstances where there is reason to hope things might start working better.

      • onPermanentError

        public void onPermanentError()
        Report a permanent error that will not go away until further notice. No operation will be scheduled until resetPermanentError() is called. Commonly used for authentication failures (which are reset when the accounts database is updated).

      • resetPermanentError

        public void resetPermanentError()
        Reset any permanent error status set by onPermanentError(), allowing operations to be scheduled as normal.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Return a string description of the scheduler state for debugging.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a printable representation of this object.

      • currentTimeMillis

        protected long currentTimeMillis()
        Gets the current time. Can be overridden for unit testing.
        Returns:
        System.currentTimeMillis()
